snippet: Violence killed at least 11 people and threw the race into disarray as some candidates blamed the military for the deaths and said they were halting their campaigns.
abstract: Assailants attack protesters staging a sit-in near Egypt's Ministry of Defense in Cairo, killing at least 11 people, setting off hours of clashes and throwing the coming presidential election into disarray; at least five candidates announce the suspension of their campaigns to protest the deaths; episode widens a rift between Egypt's military rulers and protesters who are pushing for a speedy transition to a civilian government. Photo (M)

byline.original: By KAREEM FAHIM and MAYY EL SHEIKH; Liam Stack contributed reporting

lead_paragraph: CAIRO -- As least 11 people were killed after assailants attacked protesters staging a sit-in near Egypt's Ministry of Defense early on Wednesday, setting off hours of clashes that threw the coming presidential election into disarray as at least five candidates announced the suspension of their campaigns to protest the deaths. The victims, killed by gunfire, clubs or knives, included a third-year medical student from Luxor and several young men from the Cairo neighborhood Abbaseya, where the fighting occurred, doctors said. It went for hours with no intervention from the authorities -- suggesting to some at least a degree of government complicity -- as opposing sides fought a pitched battle hurling stones and incendiary devices, turning a residential neighborhood into a war zone marked by scattered fires.

headline.main: Deadly Clashes in Egypt Throw the Presidential Race Into Disarray

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: MIDDLE EAST AND NORTH AFRICA UNREST (2010- )
